bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Otis O. Benson, Jr., April 23, 1948

div1.p: Hench asks for aerial photographs of Havana and Quemados, Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Otis O. Benson, Jr., April 23, 1948
div1.opener:
April 23, 1948
Colonel Otis O. Benson, Jr.
Chief, Medical Research Division
Office of the Air Surgeon
Department of the Air Force
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear Colonel Benson:
div1.p:
Dr. Jan Tillisch, our mutual friend, has given me your letter addressed
to him 27 February. I have just returned from Cuba. You may remember that I
was requesting Doctor Tillisch's help in getting some air views of certain
locations in Quemados (suburb of Havana), historically connected with the
conquest of yellow fever and the experimental work of Dr. Walter Reed. I have
spent some years trying to locate such photographs by interviewing and writing
places, such as the National Geographic Society, the Public Relations Department
of the Photographic Department of the U. S. Navy, Pan-American Airways, etc.
All without success.

Through the courtesy of an Air Force officer of the Cuban Army Air
Force, I did obtain during my recent trip to Cuba one or two useful views but
I could certainly use other views. Unfortunately, my Cuban Air Force friend
insisted that perpendicular views were greatly superior to tangential views.
I will not argue the point. Perpendicular views are doubtless clearer to air
force personnel but the ordinary layman gets more out of a tangential view. I
am sure you know what I am driving at.

In any event, I should still be delighted to purchase one copy each
of any views that your department should have in the neighborhood of Havana,
or adjacent Quemados de Marianao and I am therefore taking the liberty of
making the request for the photographs and their clearance to the Photographic
Records and Services Division, as you have suggested.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
